title: How to Eat Turmeric Root

steps.headline: Grate a small amount of turmeric root to add to soups.
steps.description: Turmeric adds a shot of color to whatever you use it in, so it works well in soups like chicken noodle or butternut squash. It will produce a golden hue while adding a hint of flavor. Use a chunk that's about 1 inch (2.5 cm) or so.

steps.headline: Sauté turmeric with fresh greens.
steps.description: Add a little oil or butter to a pan over medium heat, then grate ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of turmeric into the oil. Let it cook for about 30 seconds, then pile greens on top. Let the greens wilt some before adding more greens. Add enough greens to make a couple of servings, stirring as you do. You can use a bunch of kale or collard greens, or just use a bag of prewashed spinach. Add a dash of salt and pepper at the end. You can also add fresh garlic when you add the turmeric.

steps.headline: Grate turmeric into egg dishes.
steps.description: Add turmeric to scrambled eggs, omelets, or frittatas. You can even add it to egg salad. Just grate some fresh, peeled turmeric root into the eggs before you cook them or add it the egg salad mixture. Start with just a couple passes over a micro-grater your first time. Add more the next time if you like the flavor. If you're worried about the consistency, try adding it to egg dishes that already have other vegetables in them. For instance, fry garlic in a little oil or butter, then wilting fresh spinach leaves in the pan. Mix the grated turmeric in with the eggs, and pour them in the pan to scramble them.

steps.headline: Chop turmeric finely to add to salads.
steps.description: Peel off the the outside of the turmeric root. Cut off a piece, and then use a sharp knife to cut it into small pieces. Add the slivers to salads for a subtle hint of flavor. You can even add it to fruit salad or potato salad.

steps.headline: Add a chunk or two to marinades for extra flavor.
steps.description: Cut off 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) of turmeric root and peel it. Roughly chop it into smaller pieces or even crush it with the side of your knife. Add it to any marinade you'd use ginger in. You can also add it to fruity marinades, like ones that use pineapple.

steps.headline: Chop turmeric to add to grains.
steps.description: Turmeric will turn any grain dish a beautiful golden hue. Chop it finely to add to the water when you're cooking rice, lentils, or bulgur. You can also add big chunks and then just fish it out at the end before serving.

steps.headline: Substitute fresh turmeric root for dried turmeric in a recipe.
steps.description: If you have a recipe that calls for dried turmeric, you can add fresh turmeric instead. For every teaspoon (2.2 grams) of ground, dried turmeric, add 1 inch (2.5 cm) of turmeric root or 1 tablespoon (6 grams) of grated turmeric.

steps.headline: Combine turmeric with black pepper for better absorbency.
steps.description: When you use turmeric root in a dish, add a bit of black pepper, too. Black pepper helps you absorb the turmeric more readily, which may help increase its anti-inflammatory properties.

steps.headline: Brew tea with a 1/4 teaspoon (about 0.5 grams) of grated turmeric.
steps.description: Boil 1 cup (240 mL) of water on the stove, and then add the turmeric root. Mix it in, and let it simmer for about 10 minutes. If you don't like the flavor by itself, add a bit of honey or blue agave for sweetness. Lime or lemon is also good in the tea.

steps.headline: Add a piece the size of shelled peanut to your smoothie.
steps.description: Make a smoothie like you normally would, but throw in a small piece of turmeric root before blending it up. You can use it in any smoothie, but it will go especially well in smoothies that call for ginger. Substitute the turmeric for the ginger. Peel the root before adding it to your smoothie.

steps.headline: Juice turmeric root to add to drinks and dishes.
steps.description: Run turmeric root through a juicer to extract the liquid. Pour the liquid in smoothies, tea, or coffee for a touch of flavor. Add dashes to soups, salad dressings, and even dough for baked goods.

steps.headline: Make golden milk with fresh turmeric root.
steps.description: Add 1 inch (2.5 cm) of peeled turmeric root to a pan. Pour in 10 to 12 fluid ounces (300 to 350 mL) of milk or alternative milk, using whatever fat percentage you prefer. Heat the milk over medium heat, but don't allow it to come to a boil. Once it's warm, pour in honey to taste and serve warm. Some people drink this mixture when they have a cold.

steps.headline: Check international grocery stores for the root.
steps.description: Because this root is often used in dishes from other countries, you're more likely to find it at a store that carries international ingredients. Look for the root at Asian and international markets, for instance.

steps.headline: Look for the root at gourmet and health-conscious grocery stores.
steps.description: Some people see this root as a health tonic, so you might find it at natural grocers. Similarly, high-end grocery stores might carry it as specialty ingredient. If the store doesn't carry it, ask them if they might consider carrying it in the future.

steps.headline: Wrap turmeric root in a paper towel to store it in the refrigerator.
steps.description: If you cut the root, place the towel over that in end, and then wrap it over the whole root. Put the root in an airtight container or zip-top bag and stick it in the fridge for up to 2 weeks.

steps.headline: Freeze turmeric root whole.
steps.description: Scrub the roots clean under running water before putting them in a zip-top freezer bag or airtight container. Place the roots in the freezer whole, and take them out as you need them. To use the root, use a microplane to grate the frozen turmeric into your dish or drink.

steps.headline: Blend up turmeric to make turmeric cubes.
steps.description: Place peeled turmeric in a food processor or blender. Blend it up until it forms a paste. If you need to, you can add a little water to help it blend better. Pour the mixture into an ice cube tray, and place it in the freezer. Once the cubes are frozen, pop them into an airtight container or zip-top bag to use later. Pop the cubes into soups, sauces, stews, or smoothies.
